message_1: Consider a topological space $X$ that is homeomorphic to the space $S^2 \times S^1$, where $S^2$ is the 2-dimensional sphere and $S^1$ is the 1-dimensional circle. Calculate the fundamental group $\pi_1(X)$ of this space.
message_2:
Since $X$ is homeomorphic to $S^2 \times S^1$, their fundamental groups will be isomorphic. To compute the fundamental group of $S^2 \times S^1$, we can use the fact that the fundamental group of a product space is the direct product of the fundamental groups of the individual spaces.

The fundamental group of $S^2$ is trivial, i.e., $\pi_1(S^2) = \{e\}$, because $S^2$ is simply connected. The fundamental group of $S^1$ is isomorphic to the integers, i.e., $\pi_1(S^1) = \mathbb{Z}$, because $S^1$ is a circle with one "hole" and loops around it can be classified by the number of times they wind around the hole.

Therefore, the fundamental group of $S^2 \times S^1$ is the direct product of the fundamental groups of $S^2$ and $S^1$, which is $\{e\} \times \mathbb{Z} \cong \mathbb{Z}$. Thus, the fundamental group of the topological space $X$ is $\pi_1(X) \cong \mathbb{Z}$.
